chapter.title: Upgrading the system

abstract.para: SUSE offers a command-line tool to upgrade a running system to a new version. The tool provides support for “rollback” to an older release. This chapter explains how to upgrade your system step by step.

chapter.para: &slema; uses transactional updates to upgrade from one version to the next. This has the following advantages:

listitem.para: The system is always in a defined state until the first RPM is updated.
Canceling is possible until the first RPM is updated.
Simple recovery if there is an error.
It is possible to do a rollback via system tools—no backup or restore needed.

sect1.title: Upgrading to a new release

important.title: Upgrade to a new release and wicked
important.para: &slema;5.3 introduced NetworkManager as the default tool to manage networking. However, when you perform upgrade from previous releases, the default network framework remains wicked.

note.title: &suse; Linux Enterprise Live Patching
note.para: If you have the &suse; Linux Enterprise Live Patching extension enabled, the extension is not affected during the upgrade procedure.

sect1.para: If your system is registered with the &scc;, make sure to have an Internet connection during the following procedure:

step.para: The upgrade procedure is performed by calling the transactional-update:
A list of available migration targets is displayed. Enter a number.
A list of packages to be installed or updated is displayed. Press y to continue with the upgrade procedure.
To complete the upgrade, reboot your system and boot into the target version.

sect1.title: Reverting the migration process
sect1.para: If a new release does not work for you, &slema; supports reverting the system to the state before the migration process was started by using the transactional-update rollback command.
